Award.AwardTitle: The Village Ecodynamics Project CRPA Initiative: The Deep History of Pueblo People and the Neolithic Revolution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award addresses the archaeological issues surrounding the ancestral Pueblo people and their Neolithic revolution or disappearance from the Mesa Verde region of southwestern US. The research describes the people, their living conditions and the environment, their impact on the region and the reason for their exodus to form new societies such as the Tewa-Pueblo society. The research and its results are significant, from both an archaeological and socio-cultural standpoint. An exhibit is planned, to explain and inform the public, in the History Colorado Center in Denver, Colorado, that will transfer this cultural knowledge to the under-served public including Native American and numerous rural residents. The effort is a collaborative endeavor involving the Crow Canyon Archaeological Center in Cortez, Colorado and the new History Colorado Center.

The exhibit will feature a typical living area, a scientific area with discussion of tree rings, and an area for discussion with scientific experts. In addition, the deliverable will include a website for further discussion with scientist and for accessing the latest research efforts.

The evaluation of this project is extensive starting from an overall evaluation of the museum itself and how to make this exhibit a significant part of the museum, pleasing to the audiences and how to improve its impact once the exhibit is open.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Crow Canyon Archaeological Center was awarded a grant by the National Science Foundation (NSF) in their Communicating Research to Public Audiences program (NSF-CRPA); the grant was titled “The Village Ecodynamics Project CRPA Initiative: The Deep History of Pueblo People and the Neolithic Revolution.”

This grant created educational products about the results of an NSF-funded research project known as the Village Ecodynamics Project, or VEP. These educational products have a high degree of intellectual merit and positive public impact because the educational content was based on the VEP, a recognized through multiple awards as one of the world’s most important archaeological projects.

The VEP examines the long-term interaction between Pueblo Indians and their environments during the A.D. 600–1760 period. The VEP study areas include two of the world’s most important archaeological regions: the Mesa Verde region in southwestern Colorado and the northern Rio Grande region in New Mexico. The Mesa Verde region was one of the most densely settled areas within ancestral Pueblo Indian’s homeland, and the New Mexico study area is home to modern-day Pueblo Indian tribes.

VEP research integrates three major studies: 1) a detailed reconstruction of the past environment; 2) a computer simulation; and 3) the analysis of about 25,000 archaeological sites. The VEP pioneered the use of computer simulation in archaeology by recreating the past environment and then having virtual Pueblo families interact with those environments for 1,160 years. The VEP simulations examined how the centuries-long occupation impacted these environments and studied how Pueblo people coped with climate change and its effect on their subsistence resources. The VEP also developed new methods to analyze unprecedentedly large numbers of archaeological sites, producing detailed demographic reconstructions, tracking how the size and distribution of Pueblo populations changed through time.

The VEP results provide a transformative understanding of Pueblo history and perhaps the world’s best documented case of the Neolithic Revolution. Almost everyone alive today lives in a society whose roots can be traced to the Neolithic Revolution, a time when domesticated food production replaced hunting and gathering, and the VEP provides new insights into this pivotal period in human history.

The educational products created by this NSF-CRPA grant include museum exhibits and an educational website. These educational products have a broad impact on society because the content is based on the VEP results and because they reach a large and diverse audience.

The museum exhibits were installed at the new History Colorado Center in Denver, Colorado. The exhibits include a replica pueblo, an interactive exhibit on Pueblo pottery, information about turkey domestication, and the analysis of tree-rings for dating and climate reconstruction. The featured exhibit is a video kiosk that allows museum visitors to learn from archaeologists and Pueblo Indians who provide information about ancestral Pueblo Indian society and its connection to modern Pueblo Indian people. The museum exhibit opened November 22, 2013; since then visitation includes almost 200,000 people. The exhibit was praised in the Informal Learning Review, and it won the "Award of Merit" from the American Association for State and Local History.

The VEP-CRPA grant also created a website about the VEP. This website allows people from throughout the world learn about the VEP by interacting with a group of VEP scientists.
